abstracts.cdata!:
This is a project completion report of
            the Rural Services Project in Comoros. Agriculture dominates
            the country's economy, providing employment to 80
            percent of the population; contributing 40 percent to Gross
            Domestic Product (GDP), as well as virtually all export
            earnings. Agricultural production is almost entirely
            concentrated in the smallholder sector. The country is
            densely populated and, in order to meet basic family food
            requirements, government's primary objective for the
            agricultural sector has been to increase food self
            sufficiency and reduce imports through productivity
            improvements. The Federal Center for the Support to Rural
            Development (CEFADER) had been set up as the agency to
            implement the above objectives, but government envisaged for
            it a large number of projects and a rapid expansion of
            staff, thus creating serious complications as to its
            absorptive capacity and recurrent cost budget. At the time
            of project preparation, in 1982-83, the major donors who
            cooperated at field level were well aware, as was CEFADER
            management, of the need to consolidate activities into a
            clear program of action and to ensure the government had the
            budgetary capacity to continue activities once donor
            financed projects came to an end. The need for
            reorganization, for effective use, training and supervision
            of staff, for budgetary management, and for coherent
            planning within the rural services network, became an
            important priority.

docna.cdata!:
Comoros - Rural Services Project : Credit
            1469 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

display_title.display_title:
Comoros - Rural Services Project
            : Credit 1469 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the proposed project is
            to reorganize the CEFADER/CADER so that it functions
            effectively as the network for rural services. The project
            would address the problems of recurrent cost financing and
            inadequate budgetary procedures, shortage of skilled
            manpower and need for better donor coordination in the
            sector. It would improve rural extension services, training
            and supervision of staff, monitoring and planning, and
            budgetary management and finance. It would strengthen animal
            health, forestry and land conservation programs and would
            complete two new CADERs and support existing CADER
            operations. By strengthening the rural services network, the
            project would provide for a more systematic approach to
            extension, field trials and development of technical
            packages, which should lead to increased foodcrop, livestock
            and fuelwood production and better forestry management.
            Increased food and meat production would result in import
            savings. An additional benefit would be the improved
            nutritional level of the rural population. The project would
            also promote more efficient use of resources provided by
            external donors.
